channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pharaonic Funkatizing at the Met Roof Garden
item.description: Lauren Halsey built a personal monument drawing on sources from ancient Egypt to George Clinton to threatened neighborhoods of South Central Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: For her Met Roof Garden commission opening Tuesday, the artist Lauren Halsey created a monument to friends, family and South Central Los Angeles, where she lives. While it draws on the Met’s Temple of Dendur. community is the source and subject. Sphinxes depict her mother, left, and brother, right.

item.title: With Cheers and Tears, ‘Phantom of the Opera’ Ends Record Broadway Run
item.description: The show’s record-breaking 35-year Broadway run came to an end on Sunday night. Its famous chandelier got a bow, and its composer, Andrew Lloyd Webber, spoke after its emotional final performance.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: The showstopping chandelier from “The Phantom of the Opera” got its own bow after the show’s final Broadway performance.

item.title: Review: Grief and Mourning, Delivered With Ecstatic Vitality
item.description: In Gregory Maqoma’s “Cion,” performed by the Vuyani Dance Theater at the Joyce, the performers offer images of collective lamentation, prayer and hope.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas
item.media:description: Otto Andile Nhlapo, center, in the role of the central mourning figure in Gregory Maqoma’s “Cion.”

item.title: Review: András Schiff Wears Two Hats at the New York Philharmonic
item.description: Taking a cue from Mozart, András Schiff appeared with the New York Philharmonic as both piano soloist and conductor.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: ‘Barry’ Is Ending. For Anthony Carrigan, That’s Nothing to Be Afraid Of
item.description: In his Emmy-nominated role as the sunshiny Chechen gangster NoHo Hank, Carrigan has expanded what a villain can be — and his repertoire.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times

item.title: Review: Contemporary Music Champions Celebrate With the Hits
item.description: The Boston Modern Orchestra Project threw itself a sparsely attended 25th-anniversary party at Carnegie Hall. Those who didn’t go risk FOMO.
item.dc:creator: Seth Colter Walls

item.title: ‘Phantom of the Opera’ Fans Mourn the Record-Breaking Show’s End
item.description: As “The Phantom of the Opera” ends its record-breaking Broadway run on Sunday, its most devoted followers, who call themselves Phans, are mourning.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Lucia Buricelli for The New York Times

item.title: Museum Will Stop Obscuring Images of Prophet Muhammad From Online Tour
item.description: The Asia Society said the two images should not have been blurred, though it recognizes the need to display them in context since many Muslims object to depictions of Muhammad as sacrilegious.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: Review: In a Sorkinized ‘Camelot,’ That’s How Conditions Are. Alas.
item.description: A revival of the 1960 musical with the famously great score and infamously bad book gets a gorgeous makeover that makes no difference.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.media:description: Andrew Burnap, left, as Arthur and Phillipa Soo as Guenevere in the musical “Camelot” at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

item.title: ‘Saturday Night Live’: Ana de Armas and the First Warm Day of the Year
item.description: The “Blonde” star was the host and Karol G was the musical guest on an episode that was light on topical moments.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff

item.title: Nina Ananiashvili Brings the State Ballet of Georgia to New York
item.description: Ananiashvili’s company, the State Ballet of Georgia, presents a program of works by George Balanchine and Yuri Possokhov at the Lehman Center in the Bronx.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.media:credit: Melissa Lyttle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nina Ananiashvili, the former American Ballet Theater and Bolshoi star, now leads the State Ballet of Georgia, which is on a U.S. tour.

item.title: A Director and a Rock Band Are Redrawing the Contours of Anime
item.description: For hits like “Your Name” and now “Suzume,” Makoto Shinkai has worked with Radwimps on the narrative as well as the score. The results have won awards.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar

item.title: An Uptown Cat Became a Chinese Artist. Then He Returned Home.
item.description: After 15 years in Beijing, Miguel Ángel Payano came back to New York, at ease with Afro-Caribbean, Latino and Asian cultures. What he never expected was a Parkinson’s diagnosis.
item.dc:creator: Siddhartha Mitter
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miguel Ángel Payano Jr. in his studio in the Bronx. An exhibition of his new work, made in both Beijing and New York, is currently on view at the Charles Moffett Gallery.

item.title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Amityville: An Origin Story’ and ‘Revengineers’
item.description: A docuseries on MGM+ delves into the history of the real Amityville house of horrors, and a new prank show from Mark Rober and Jimmy Kimmel premieres on Discovery.
item.dc:creator: Kristen Bayrakdarian
item.media:description: Christopher Quaratino in “Amityville: An Origin Story.”

item.title: Live ‘Love Is Blind’ Reunion on Netflix Is Delayed, Vexing Fans
item.description: The streaming service, which was making a rare foray into live content, left fans hanging for more than an hour as they signed in to watch a highly anticipated reunion episode.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: Netflix’s highly anticipated live reunion episode of “Love Is Blind” did not go up on time on Sunday night, frustrating fans.

item.title: ‘Succession’ Season 4, Episode 4 Recap: A Coronation Demolition Derby
item.description: Just when Logan’s inner circle thinks that it might finally be free of his mercurial nature, he springs one more annoying surprise.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: The Best Books to Read in 2023
item.description: Finding a book you’ll love can be daunting. Let us help.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Books Staff

item.title: Book Review: ‘My Cousin Maria Schneider,’ by Vanessa Schneider
item.description: In a troubling new memoir, Vanessa Schneider contends that the sexually explicit 1972 film exploited, and irrevocably hurt, her cousin.
item.dc:creator: Thessaly La Force
item.media:description: Maria Schneider in a scene from the 1972 film “Last Tango in Paris.”

item.title: The Phantom of the Opera Is Here, Inside The Times
item.description: As Broadway’s longest-running show headed to a close on Sunday after more than 35 years, New York Times employees shared their memories.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Joy Oladokun’s Therapeutic Folk-Pop Searches for Hope. It’s Resonating.
item.description: The singer-songwriter with Springsteen aspirations wants to make music for everyone. Her new album, “Proof of Life,” pushes her one step closer.
item.dc:creator: Marissa R. Moss
item.media:credit: Kristine Potter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oladokun’s goal is to make music for everyone: “Even people I don’t agree with.”

item.title: ‘The Tale of Genji’ Is More Than 1,000 Years Old. What Explains Its Lasting Appeal?
item.description: The book is often described as the world’s first novel and a touchstone of Japanese literature. But some of its themes, including its take on gender and power, have echoed over centuries.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

item.title: Book Review: ‘Stalking Shakespeare: A Memoir of Madness, Murder, and My Search for the Poet Beneath the Paint,’ by Lee Durkee
item.description: In “Stalking Shakespeare,” Lee Durkee describes his quest to find a true, authentic image of the famous playwright, a search that becomes a tragicomic tale in its own right.
item.dc:creator: Dominic Dromgoole

item.title: How I Chose Among the Translations of ‘The Tale of Genji’
item.description: There have been several major English translations of Murasaki Shikibu’s 11th-century classic. Motoko Rich, The Times’s Tokyo bureau chief, discusses how she approached them.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

item.title: Ishay Ribo, Religious Pop Star, Is Winning Over Secular Israel
item.description: The songs of Ishay Ribo, who was raised in a settlement on the West Bank, are a staple of Israeli radio. He is part of a wave of singers from religious backgrounds who are also gaining a wider audience.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ishay Ribo performing at a culture hall in Kibbutz Gan Shmuel, Israel, in January.

item.title: Keith Johnstone, Champion of Improvisational Theater, Dies at 90
item.description: The theatrical games and performance techniques Mr. Johnstone developed became a familiar part of the acting arsenal.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: Keith Johnstone teaching a course on “directing work and improvisations on a comic text” at the Royal Court Theater in London in 1963.

item.title: Edward Koren, 87, Whose Cartoon Creatures Poked Fun at People, Dies
item.description: For six decades in The New Yorker and elsewhere, his hairy, toothy, long-nosed characters offered witty commentary on the foibles of the American middle class.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

item.title: Review: Ayodele Casel Shares the Floor With Varied Visions of Tap
item.description: At New York City Center, a characteristically generous Casel presents works by other choreographers as well as her own “Where We Dwell V.2.”
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Burke
item.media:credit: Rachel Papo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ayodele Casel, center, with Jared Alexander, left, and Izaiah Montaque Harris in “Where We Dwell V.2.”

item.title: ‘The Phantom of the Opera’: Thinking of a Spectacle Fondly
item.description: As the longest-running musical in Broadway history closes, Times critics with a lasting affection for the show take stock of its legacy.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone, Alexis Soloski and Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:description: “The Phantom of the Opera” opened in 1988. The Majestic Theater’s marquee just before a May 1988 performance.

item.title: 10 Reasons to Rediscover John Cale
item.description: A listening tour of the musician’s wildly eclectic seven-decade career.
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

item.title: The Steps to Making ‘How to Blow Up a Pipeline’
item.description: The filmmakers and cast of “How to Blow Up a Pipeline” explain what it took to quickly, but precisely, put together their indie tale of sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Rapold
item.category: How to Blow Up a Pipeline (Movie)

item.title: Kelly Clarkson Starts Telling Her Story, and 7 More New Songs
item.description: Hear tracks by Jorja Smith, Romy, Speedy Ortiz and others.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: ‘The Pope’s Exorcist’ Review: A Head-Spinning Genre Mash-Up
item.description: The buddy-priest action-comedy-horror hybrid we didn’t know we wanted has finally landed.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:description: Daniel Zovatto and Russell Crowe add a dollop of buddy-priest action comedy to an already genre-full plate in “The Pope’s Exorcist,” our critic writes.

item.title: ‘Barry’ by Bullet Point: What to Remember Before Season 4 Begins
item.description: Is there still time for Barry to find redemption? He has one season left to figure it out. Here’s where the show left off at the end of Season 3.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Vineyard

item.title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
item.description: Deadly planets and deadly viruses must be contended with in this month’s selections.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:description: Nuno Nolasco and Maria Leite in “Infinite Sea.”

item.title: Wherever These Surgeries Went, the Camera Did, Too
item.description: In a radical experiment, the filmmakers Véréna Paravel and Lucien Castaing-Taylor sought a scalpel-level view of operations in French hospitals.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.media:description: Doctors were active collaborators in “De Humani Corporis Fabrica,” introducing the filmmakers to other physicians and patients.

item.title: Livestreaming ‘Made All the Difference’ for Some Disabled Art Lovers
item.description: When shuttered venues embraced streaming during the pandemic, the arts became more accessible. With live performance back, and streams dwindling, many feel forgotten.
item.dc:creator: Neelam Bohra and Wendy Lu
item.media:description: Richard Nelson’s “What Do We Need to Talk About?” was streamed live in 2020. Clockwise from upper left: Maryann Plunkett and Jay O. Sanders, Sally Murphy, Stephen Kunken and Laila Robins.

item.title: Exploring Picasso’s Málaga
item.description: Among the best places to discover the celebrated 20th-century Spanish artist is the sun-splashed, seaside city where he was born.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ferren
item.media:credit: Emilio Parra Doiztua for The New York Times
item.media:description: Picasso was born in the port city of Málaga in 1881, and lived there until he was 9 years old. Above, Calle Larios, the city’s main shopping and pedestrian street.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Beauty of Ukraine,’ by Yevhen Samuchenko and Lucia Bondar
item.description: A book of photographs taken before February 2022 reveals formerly breathtaking landscapes that may never be the same.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Christensen
item.media:description: Early-1900s wooden poles used for salt mining on the Kuialnyk Estuary, on the northwest coast of the Black Sea.

item.title: 40 Years Later, The Return of Halley’s Day-Glo Comet
item.description: With four shows of work from the ’80s traveling the globe, the artist is still seeing what he can get away with.
item.dc:creator: Max Lakin
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Halley recently in his Manhattan studio with his work from 1981, “The Big Jail,” which will be seen at Karma in New York. His works, with their hermetic chambers, had a premonitory quality.

item.title: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: Hunter/Gatherer
item.description: Teen Lottie goes out in search of prey as her allies back at the cabin become more and more like followers.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:description: Lottie (Courtney Eaton) went on a strange journey this week in “Yellowjackets.” It wasn’t based entirely in reality.

item.title: ‘The Last Kingdom: Seven Kings Must Die’ Review: Flesh Wounds
item.description: Soldiers face off over the fate of England in this overbearingly glib costume drama.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels
item.category: The Last Kingdom: Seven Kings Must Die (Movie)
item.media:description: Alexander Dreymon in “The Last Kingdom: Seven Kings Must Die.”

item.title: Stephen Colbert Can Tell When Fox News Is Lying
item.description: A judge said he would probably appoint a “special master” to investigate whether Fox had misled the court. The “Late Show” host thinks he’s up to the job.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Late Late Show with James Corden (TV Program)

item.title: Llano County Keeps Public Libraries Open Amid Book Ban Controversy
item.description: Officials in Llano County considered closing the entire library system in lieu of returning challenged titles to its shelves.
item.dc:creator: David Montgomery and Alexandra Alter
item.media:description: The fight in Llano County, in central Texas, has become a test case for whether courts will continue to uphold First Amendment protections for libraries in the face of rising book bans.

item.title: Leonard Abrams, 68, Chronicler of 1980s East Village Art Boom, Dies
item.description: His newspaper, the East Village Eye, was as scrappy and iconoclastic as the young maverick stars its pages brought to life.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Pierre Lacotte, Choreographer Who Aided a Defection, Dies at 91
item.description: He befriended Rudolf Nureyev in 1961 while the Kirov Ballet was in Paris and witnessed his headline-making defection at the height of the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: Pierre Lacotte in 1964 performing in the ballet “Penthésilée” with his wife, Ghislaine Thesmar. As a choreographer, Mr. Lacotte was best known for restaging 19th-century ballets.

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: “Barry” is back for its final season, as intense and dazzling as ever.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons
item.media:description: Bill Hader in a scene from the season premiere of “Barry.”

item.title: Meir Shalev, Whose Novels Found Humor in Israeli Life, Dies at 74
item.description: He focused mostly on the half-century before Israeli independence, finding the plight of the early Zionists ripe for affectionate satire.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger
item.media:description: Meir Shalev in 2007. His novels, nonfiction and children’s books made him one of Israel’s leading writers.

item.title: Rachel Pollack, Transgender Activist and Authority on Tarot, Dies at 77
item.description: Her science fiction writing won awards. Her tarot books won her a devoted following. And she created DC Comics’ first transgender superhero.
item.dc:creator: George Gene Gustines
item.category: Seventy-Eight Degrees of Wisdom: A Tarot Journey to Self-Awareness (Book)

item.title: Lady Gaga, Shonda Rhimes and More Named to Restored Arts Commission
item.description: The President’s Committee on the Arts and the Humanities, disbanded during the Trump administration, mixes scholars with boldface names from the entertainment world.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.category: President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities
Institute of Museum and Library Services
item.media:description: Lady Gaga, who performed at a drive-in rally for Joe Biden during the 2020 campaign, will be the co-chair of the restored President’s Committee on the Arts and Humanities.

item.title: Review: In ‘Hamnet,’ Shakespeare Becomes Soap Opera
item.description: The Royal Shakespeare Company adaptation of Maggie O’Farrell’s hit 2020 novel is elegant and tasteful — but also formulaic and sentimental.
item.dc:creator: Houman Barekat

item.title: ‘Personality Crisis: One Night Only’ Review: New York Droll
item.description: David Johansen, once the lead singer for the New York Dolls, proves a first-rate raconteur in this documentary co-directed by Martin Scorsese and David Tedeschi.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy
item.media:description: If Café Carlyle delivers the chic, David Johansen brings the funk to “Personality Crisis: One Night Only.”

item.title: Broadway Show “Shucked” Celebrates Corn in Every Way Possible
item.description: “Shucked” is the first Broadway show in which the breakout star is a vegetable, served up in a cornucopia of puns.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:description: The musical “Shucked,” which opened April 4, depends on corn for its story line and many, many punchlines.

item.title: ‘Renfield’ Review: Dracula, Worst Boss Ever
item.description: Nicholas Hoult stars as the long-suffering servant to Nicolas Cage’s Count Dracula in this highly absurd, entertaining comedy.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.media:description: Nicholas Hoult, left, as the put-upon servant to Nicolas Cage’s imperious Dracula in “Renfield.”

item.title: ‘Television’ Review: Small-Screen Dreams
item.description: A new show at the Wild Project in Manhattan imagines how a small 1950s community weathers the arrival of the mass media age.
item.dc:creator: Juan A. Ramírez

item.title: ‘Hilma’ Review: An Artist With Spirit
item.description: The film gets off to a rough start, but the director wins the audience back with his sincere connection to the artist Hilma af Klint.
item.dc:creator: Amy Nicholson
item.media:description: “Hilma” focuses on the mystical artist Hilma af Klint, who believed that spirits guided her to paint.

item.title: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 3, Episode 9 Recap: A Familiar Home
item.description: Home is where the ship is. In this week’s episode of “Picard,” the crew goes home.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:description: Poor Jean-Luc (Patrick Stewart). First he finds out he has unwittingly been an absentee father, and now he may have accidentally turned his son into a homicidal robot.

item.title: When Is a Chair a Work of Art? A Bushwick Gallery Weighs In
item.description: In a furniture store, it’s a chair. In an art gallery, it’s a sculpture. But at International Objects in Brooklyn, it could be either, neither or both.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Four “Inflated Aluminum Chairs” (2021) by Zachary Besner have a sculptural panache when displayed all together — but they’re also surprisingly comfortable to sit in.

item.title: ‘Suzume’ Review: Gods, Spells and Instagram Posts
item.description: Makoto Shinkai’s latest animated film, about a girl who accidentally unleashes chaos over Japan, is at once mythical and thoroughly modern.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips
item.media:description: The title character in “Suzume” is a 17-year-old girl whose sidekick is a man turned into a three-legged chair.

item.title: ‘Passion’ Review: Friends Fall Apart
item.description: Belatedly making its U.S. debut, a 2008 film from Ryusuke Hamaguchi (“Drive My Car”) offers new insights into his abiding themes and sensibilities.
item.dc:creator: Austin Considine
item.media:description: Aoba Kawai and Ryuta Okamoto in “Passion.”

item.title: Spotlighting Lady Macbeth’s Anguish: Can What’s Done Be Undone?
item.description: With radical adaptations of Verdi’s “Macbeth” and Puccini’s “Tosca,” Heartbeat Opera shows why it’s so vital to New York’s music scene.
item.dc:creator: Oussama Zahr
